text: hi i'm brianna frank and i'm so excited
to be here at kubecon
even though it's virtual and today i'm
going to talk about
the kubernetes effect igniting
transformation in your team
and so when we talk about transformation
really the goal of any transformation is
to move faster
and when we're adopting cloud native uh
capabilities and
and tactics of course we want to have
resiliency and scale and availability
but really it's about pushing as much
code as possible every single day
and you know in ibm cloud we're pushing
thousands of updates a day to our
production cloud
and what's interesting is many of our
clients ask
as a 100 old tech company how did you
transform to this level of velocity and
what are the ways that our organizations
can
you know ignite that transformation and
so i
i give a couple of examples i'm sure i
don't have it all figured out but
a couple of things that i think that we
found that that have really worked
you know one start with a new project
and whenever you start with something
new it allows you to reevaluate
everything that you're doing chances are
your teams are
have inherited legacy software and
systems
and processes and they're you know by
starting with something new you can
reevaluate
everything that you're doing you know
maybe you're improving some things and
leaving some
an additional processes out but it gives
you a fresh start
and the other thing i recommend is a
design thinking workshop
and you know we're big we're big in
design thinking here at ibm but
what design thinking is about is to take
two or three days and i know that sounds
like a luxury
but take that time to bring all of your
stakeholders into one room
and hash out what your mvp is going to
look like
and if you have a really strong design
facilitator they will
work they will work with you to walk you
through some exercises that allows you
to
exit that workshop with quantifiable
hills
and when you leave everyone is very
clear on what that mvp is
and what they they need to do next
to reach that mvp so there's no
confusion and you could just move very
quickly
the next thing i recommend is starting
that new project on kubernetes
and kubernetes is a catalyst for
transformation because
um kuberes manages infrastructure in
such a consistent way
and allows dev and operations to um
operate very consistently and it
unburdens the team so the teams aren't
having to worry about resiliency and
scale
so that paves the way for a culture of
automation
and automation and automation culture is
is very addicting and it catches on very
quickly
and you know maybe it starts out with
something very simple
perhaps you start answering questions
instead of typing them out every time
you answer with a doc link and that
becomes a little bit addicting because
you see
how much time it saves and so then it
starts to transform into
any time you start to get a repeat
question instead of answering it you
open a github issue
and your product or the documentation
begins to change because
it's just more efficient and that kind
of culture
starts to really um permeate in
um you know in when you're leveraging
a technology like kubernetes and so one
of the examples that we used early on
um was chat ops and chat apps was really
born
out of wanting the ability to operate
cube but still but using the tool that
we
use or utilize to collaborate with
others and so we use slack to
collaborate with our team
but we were having to exit slack to
handle a lot of our operations
and so we have a lot of fun with chat
apps each of our chat bots has its own
persona
and a specific job in this particular
case
we use sir topham hatt and sir topham
hatt has a specific job
of course inspired by thomas the tank
engine but
search album hat handles all of our
automated gate approvals
um from for our pipeline from dev all
the way to production
and we have other chat bots that help us
with things like
recommending run books or giving us
additional information about a specific
ip address and what's neat is as we're
conversing with our peers
the chat bots um you know in
ads it add context to those
conversations
and sometimes the chat bots even talk to
each other
so another example of how we're using
automation
is razzy and so razzie.io
is an open source project that we built
out of necessity and when you're running
tens of thousands of clusters in
production
there you need to have an ability to
deploy and automate those
and so we needed an ability to view and
view all of those deployments all over
the world and what data centers
and we needed to be able to see what
clusters needed to be updated
and so we we used razzie.io
as a way to achieve that and because
we're
able to operate in a consistent way
we were able to keep our small sre team
from
um that we started with when we had zero
clusters all the way
to 24 000 clusters which is what we're
running today and none of that would be
possible without
um being able to build on the foundation
of kubernetes and because we're managing
resources in a consistent way
kubernetes enables this automation and
therefore
this transformation that allows us to go
so much faster
so that's how we're using kubernetes to
ignite transformation in our team
i would love to hear about how you're
using kube to
ignite transformation in your team and
you know find me on twitter i'm frankly
brianna but also
you know if you want to know more about
you know
if you want to know more about design
thinking or chat ops or razzie.io
i have a blog um ibm.biz transformed
where i go into a lot more detail and
have some resources there
thank you so much thanks for having me
